prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
The mid-infrared PAH strength converts to a line flux of 100 mJy for the CO(1-0) line in this source, assuming the PAH/CO relation from Pope et al. (2013, this relation was used for all our proposed targets). We aim for a 10-sigma detection of the CO(1-0) line with peak flux of 100 mJy/beam with the 12m array. The effective rms sensitivity needed is thus 10 mJy in the central resolution element.
This is easily attained in 2 mins of time on-source, if we use the 937 MHz bandwidth setup, spectrally averaged by a factor of 16. The continuum is expected to be a factor of a few fainter than in NGC 1068, but continuum measurement is not our primary goal here.
Our primary goal is detection of the line and measurement of its flux, rather than line profile determination. So we used the expected line width for the sensitivity calculation.

We expect CO(1-0) line widths of order 100 km/s. This setup provides enough bandwidth to include the line and sample the local continuum. It also allows a measurement of the continuum in the lower sideband, which can be simultaneously observed (for 'free') though this is not our primary goal.

The angular resolution of the map is chosen to be 0.4 arcsec to match our mid-IR PSF. We are mainly interested in the innermost (central) beam for this galaxy, closely corresponding to ~100 pc physical scale.

The total expected CO line flux in this system is 560 mJy, estimated from the measured PAH flux within the central 0.36 arcsec by Esquej et al. (2014). This region corresponds to our ALMA synthesized beam. Thus, we aim for a nominal 10-sigma detection of the CO(1-0) line with peak flux of 560 mJy/beam with the 12m array. The effective rms sensitivity needed is thus 56 mJy in the central resolution element.
This is easily attained in 2 mins of time on-source, if we use the 937 MHz bandwidth setup, spectrally averaged by a factor of 16. But given the brightness of this object, a much higher signal:noise is attainable in the nominal ~2 mins Science Goal exposure time, allowing us to search for other interesting characteristics (e.g. gas kinematical signatures).
The broad bandwidth will also allow a good determination of the continuum in the lower sideband, which can be simultaneously observed (for 'free'), although continuum measurement is not our primary interest here. The continuum flux is estimated by extrapolating the band 7 observation published by Garcia-Burillo et al. (2014) to band 3, though is uncertain by a factor of a few because of potential synchrotron contribution. Combining archival data on this source at multiple frequencies, we will be able to disentangle the synchrotron and thermal contribution on scales of ~0.4 arcsec in detail for the first time.

We expect CO(1-0) line widths of order 100 km/s. This setup provides enough bandwidth to include the line and sample the local continuum. It also allows a good determination of the continuum in the lower sideband, which can be simultaneously observed (for 'free').

The angular resolution of the map is chosen to be 0.4 arcsec to match our mid-IR PSF. We are mainly interested in the central 1.4 arcsec (~100 pc) this galaxy, a small area about three times wider than the synthesized beam.
This source has archival ALMA observations, but not in the CO(1-0) line. We will improve upon previously-published data by Schinnerer et al. (2000)

We aim for a 10-sigma detection of the CO(1-0) line with peak flux of 20 mJy/beam with the 12m array. The effective rms sensitivity needed is thus 2 mJy in the central resolution element.
This is easily attained in 2 mins of time on-source, if we use the 937 MHz bandwidth setup, spectrally averaged by a factor of 16. The continuum is expected to be a factor of a few fainter than in NGC 1068, but continuum measurement is not our primary goal here.
Our primary goal is detection of the line and measurement of its flux, rather than line profile determination. So we used the expected line width for the sensitivity calculation.

We expect CO(1-0) line widths of order 100 km/s. This setup provides enough bandwidth to include the line and sample the local continuum. It also allows a measurement of the continuum in the lower sideband, which can be simultaneously observed (for 'free') though this is not our primary goal.
The angular resolution of the map is chosen to be 0.4 arcsec to match our mid-IR PSF. We are mainly interested in the central beam for this galaxy.

We aim for a 10-sigma detection of the CO(1-0) line with peak flux of 20 mJy/beam with the 12m array. The effective rms sensitivity needed is thus 2 mJy in the central resolution element.
This is easily attained in 2 mins of time on-source, if we use the 937 MHz bandwidth setup, spectrally averaged by a factor of 16. The continuum is expected to be a factor of a few fainter than in NGC 1068, but continuum measurement is not our primary goal here.
Our primary goal is detection of the line and measurement of its flux, rather than line profile determination. So we used the expected line width for the sensitivity calculation.

We expect CO(1-0) line widths of order 100 km/s. This setup provides enough bandwidth to include the line and sample the local continuum. It also allows a measurement of the continuum in the lower sideband, which can be simultaneously observed (for 'free') though this is not our primary goal.
The angular resolution of the map is chosen to be 0.4 arcsec to match our mid-IR PSF. We are mainly interested in the central beam for this galaxy.

We expect HCO+ and HCN line widths of order 200 km/s. This setup provides enough bandwidth to include the line and sample the local continuum. Note that are primarily interested in the lines and not accurate continuum determination.

The angular resolution of the map is chosen to be 0.4 arcsec to match our mid-IR PSF. We are mainly interested in the innermost (central) beam for this galaxy, closely corresponding to ~100 pc physical scale.

We aim for a 10-sigma detection of the faintest line, which is HCO+(4-3) with peak flux of 10 mJy/beam with the 12m array. This estimate is based upon extrapolation from NGC 1068 where the peak nuclear HCO+ flux is 10 times fainter than CO(1-0). The effective rms sensitivity needed is thus 1 mJy in the central resolution element.
This is easily attained in 2 mins of time on-source, if we use the 937 MHz bandwidth setup, spectrally averaged by a factor of 16.
The CO(3-2) line is expected to be at least 4 times brighter than HCO+(4-3) based upon observations of NGC 1068 by Garcia-Burillo et al. (2014).

We expect HCO+ and HCN line widths of order 200 km/s. This setup provides enough bandwidth to include the line and sample the local continuum. Note that are primarily interested in the lines and not accurate continuum determination.

The angular resolution of the map is chosen to be 0.4 arcsec to match our mid-IR PSF. We are mainly interested in the innermost (central) beam for this galaxy, closely corresponding to ~100 pc physical scale.

We aim for a 10-sigma detection of the faintest line, which is HCO+(4-3) with peak flux of 2 mJy/beam with the 12m array. This estimate is based upon extrapolation from NGC 1068 where the peak nuclear HCO+ flux is 10 times fainter than CO(1-0). The effective rms sensitivity needed is thus 0.2 mJy in the central resolution element.
This is attained in 35 mins of time on-source, if we use the 937 MHz bandwidth setup, spectrally averaged by a factor of 16.
The CO(3-2) line is expected to be at least 4 times brighter than HCO+(4-3) based upon observations of NGC 1068 by Garcia-Burillo et al. (2014).

We expect HCO+ and HCN line widths of order 200 km/s. This setup provides enough bandwidth to include the line and sample the local continuum. Note that are primarily interested in the lines and not accurate continuum determination.

The angular resolution of the map is chosen to be 0.4 arcsec to match our mid-IR PSF. We are mainly interested in the innermost (central) two beams, which will nicely cover a physical scale of ~100 pc.

We aim for a 10-sigma detection of the faintest line, which is HCO+(4-3) with peak flux of 2 mJy/beam with the 12m array. This estimate is based upon extrapolation from NGC 1068 where the peak nuclear HCO+ flux is 10 times fainter than CO(1-0). The effective rms sensitivity needed is thus 0.2 mJy in the central resolution element.
This is attained in 35 mins of time on-source, if we use the 937 MHz bandwidth setup, spectrally averaged by a factor of 16.
The CO(3-2) line is expected to be at least 4 times brighter than HCO+(4-3) based upon observations of NGC 1068 by Garcia-Burillo et al. (2014).

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: The presence of an apparent connection between star-formation and accretion activity is often cited in observational studies of AGN host galaxies, and is required by models of symbiotic black hole and galaxy growth. Yet, it is strange that such a connection should exist, because of the vastly different physical scales between the global (~kpc-scale) star-formation and the (nuclear) accretion activity, meaning that any single gas reservoir cannot causally connect the two. What is required is a study of star-formation and concurrent AGN fuelling on physical scales that could be connected by a single gas flow. Here, we propose a pilot study to measure the mass of the cold and the dense gas reservoirs in 4 actively-growing local Seyferts on scales of 0."4 (physical scales <100 pc) matched to our recent high angular resolution mid-infrared AGN imaging studies with the VLT. We will search for differences in the mass, density and distribution of gas distinguishing those sources with ongoing circumnuclear star-formation, from those without. Only with ALMA can we measure the gas distribution on scales exquisitely matched to the star-formation-heated dust on the innermost AGN scales.

prp:PrincipalInvestigator.prp:organisation: School of Physics and Astronomy, Southampton, University of
